reviews.review_msg: The best professor I've had in my postsecondary education. Wildly engaging, so down to earth, and always so excited to be there and to actually hear our opinions in group discussions. Wildly clear in expectations and grading. Made two 3-hour lectures a week (intersession) very bearable, and I was always happy to be there.
He is amazing! Loved his course! Lectures get a little boring at the end but that's not his fault. He gives great feedback and grading is very clear.

Masahiro is the best professor I have ever had at SFU. He cares deeply about his students on a personal and academic level. His lectures are engaging, and provides lots of room for class discussions. He truly wants his students to succeed and is very accommodating. 10/10
A prof who truly cares about his students. His lectures are such a safe place where everyone is encouraged to share and contribute. His assignments are fair and thought-provoking.

Masa is such an inspiration and so caring/thoughtful! He creates a safe atmosphere where everyone can share without worrying about being wrong. He sees the devotion people put in the class, and those are rewarded for it. He quickly responds to emails and will do his best to answer any questions. Hard work pays off!

Masa is a really caring professor who wants you to do well. Going to class is a must as he takes attendance for marks and you also have in class activities for marks. Readings are barely mentioned and I rarely did them, as there's no exams. Journal reflections are easy marks as well. there is a term paper at the end. No textbook. Would recommend.

Masa is an understanding, kind and dependable prof who really knows his stuff and is admired by all students. His lectures can go a little slow, but he welcomes discussion which makes the course more engaging and interesting. No exams, just projects and papers. Would take a class with him again!

Paul's a very nice prof but structures his class to very confusing and difficult to succeed in, though it isnt his intent. The syllabus, lecture slides, assignments have so many pages yet still not clear of what he expects. The final is a few weeks away and he isnt even sure what it'll be like so we cant even prepare adequately for it.

Paul is an incredibly tough grader and his grading criteria are really vague. The syllabus is extremely long and extremely confusing, maybe because there are SO MANY (time consuming) assignments in this course. AVOID

Paul cares about his students and that's pretty motivating. Although his grading criteria is extremely unclear/vague, but he's looking for something soo specific. Overall, he's disorganized so you'll have to figure out pretty much everything yourself. He's a good guy though, just not a great prof.

This is the worst course I've ever taken at SFU. He gives a million in-depth assignments with little to no specified criteria & his lectures are confusing & dry. He doesn't stick to his syllabus and assignments pop up randomly you have to keep checking canvas. His quizzes are poorly worded & he shuts you down if you ask questions during lecture.

I thought Paul was very nice and caring. You can tell that he cares about all of his students, even the ones who don't talk in class. Sometimes we would share our discussions and he gave us really good feedback. He's the type to encourage and the type to believe that there's no right/wrong answer.

He's a very nice prof, but his slides are super dry. He gave us, what felt like, a million assignments. He emphasizes the importance of learning rather than the grades. But with that many assignments, you can't help but focus more on the grades lmao. There was like 3 small assignments, 2 big ones, 1 presentation, and 1 cumulative final exam.

He is a different kind of professor who really appreciates people that participate during lectures. First few weeks of lectures (when there were no student presentations) felt rushed and lacked visual aids which made it dry. Lectures were always 3 hours and VERY structured. He tries to lighten the mood though. Marking overall is fair.

She is super nice and friendly. She teaches things so you will remember them not to give you a grade. She marks easy if you give her thoughtful responses and put effort into it. Interesting and fun course.

Participation *really* matters in this class! A lot of class discussions, small group discussions.. a lot of group activities (which were fun because they were very interactive). A lot of writing, but mainly for your own learning and what your views are in multicultural theories & counseling. No grading throughout, but that wasn't a problem for me.

Nothing was marked. There's no way of knowing how grades were assigned. Sharalyn was unreachable by email, and did not offer office hours. The Canvas page was nearly impossible to navigate. Classwork was great (discussions and exercises were engaging). This would be an excellent course if she had a TA to mark assignments and answer emails.

Did not receive a single grade all term. No feedback on any assignments. When you asked for feedback, all you got was "You are doing great, don't worry!" They are very kind, but it doesn't mean anything when you have no idea how you are doing in the course.

Although kind + supportive, Sharalyn was incredibly disorganized. Canvas was a mess with many dead links and random files. No clear guidelines on assignment requirements and grading criteria. No grades were given throughout the entire semester so academic standing was 100% unknown. Discussions were great but overall it was unnecessarily stressful.

Terribly disorganized. Canvas was a joke: mostly outdated files. I could never do the readings before class because I didn't know what to read. Does not respond to emails. Kind person, but lack of organization and lack of clarity of expectations made this an incredibly stressful class. Such a disappointment: I was looking forward to this class.

Group project worth 70% of grade. Out of the 6 submitted assignments, only received a grade for 1 of them (worth 5 points) all semester, hence final grade was assigned with practically 0 indication as to why. Organized during class, but MIA/unprofessional outside class. however, very kind personality/teaching style, engaging lecture.

Sharalyn is passionate about her research and very informative. However, she doesn't care about her students.  She told us to study the wrong chapter for a quiz and didn't even apologize. She also doesn't post grades on Canvas, so it's hard to have an idea about your performance in this class. 1 word: MESS, but it's an engaging class.

interesting topics but frustrating prof. disorganized course planning, unclear expectations & grading criteria, hands back work late, don't reply to emails when you need her to, 2 big papers worth 50% all due at end of the semester, confusing on canvas, too much work. willing to help & a great reflective listener but i regretted taking this class.
